caption:
Table 1: Quantitative comparison on MSRVTT-Personalization. 
We compare Video Alchemist with state-of-the-art personalization methods across multiple metrics, including text similarity (Text-S), video similarity (Vid-S), subject similarity (Subj-S), face similarity (Face-S), and dynamic degree (Dync-D). The top and bottom tables show the evaluations for subject and face modes, respectively. †For text-to-image models, outputs are treated as single-frame videos without evaluating temporal quality. We evaluate Video Alchemist with the videos at 512⁢p⁢x×288⁢p⁢x512px288px512\mathrm{px}\times 288\mathrm{px}512 roman_p roman_x × 288 roman_p roman_x resolution. We highlight the top two models for the single reference image setting.
description: Table 1 presents a quantitative comparison of Video Alchemist against state-of-the-art video personalization methods using the MSRVTT-Personalization benchmark.  Multiple metrics assess performance: Text Similarity (how well the generated video matches the text prompt), Video Similarity (similarity to ground truth video), Subject Similarity (how well subject identity is preserved), Face Similarity (specifically for faces), and Dynamic Degree (measures the naturalness of motion). The table is split into sections for 'Subject Mode' (evaluating full-body subjects) and 'Face Mode' (evaluating only face regions).  Text-to-image models are treated as single frames since they lack temporal information.  Video Alchemist results are shown at 512x288 pixel resolution, and the top two models for the single-reference image setting are highlighted.

caption:
Table 2: User preference study. 
We show the user preference percentage for subject (left) and face modes (right), respectively.
description: This table presents the results of a user preference study comparing different video personalization models.  Participants were asked to indicate their preference for the quality and fidelity of videos generated using either full subject images (subject mode) or face crops only (face mode). The percentages shown represent the proportion of times each model was preferred for each mode.

DreamVideo [75] 0.5% 0.5%
Video Alchemist 96.5% 98.1%
caption:
Table 3: Ablation study for the subject mode. 
We use a single reference image for each model and examine three control factors. The experiments are conducted on the videos at 256⁢p⁢x×144⁢p⁢x256px144px256\mathrm{px}\times 144\mathrm{px}256 roman_p roman_x × 144 roman_p roman_x resolution.
description: This ablation study investigates the impact of three key factors on the performance of the Video Alchemist model in subject mode: the choice of image encoder, the use of word tokens, and the application of data augmentation techniques.  The experiments are performed on videos with a resolution of 256x144 pixels, using a single reference image for each model in a controlled setting to isolate the effects of each variable.  The results quantify the effects of each factor on text and video similarity, subject fidelity, and dynamic degree.

caption:
Table 4: Training augmentations. 
We denote the height and width of the reference image as hℎhitalic_h and w𝑤witalic_w.
description: This table details the data augmentation techniques used during the training of the Video Alchemist model.  It lists various augmentations applied to the reference images (downscaling, Gaussian blur, color jittering, brightness adjustment, horizontal flipping, shearing along the x and y axes, rotation, and random cropping), along with their probability of application and the specific parameters or ranges used for each.  The height (h) and width (w) of the original reference image are used to define some of the parameter ranges for augmentations like downscaling and shearing.
section: A.3. Data Augmentation and Conditional Images Sampling

caption: Table 5: Architecture details of video generation backbone and image encoders.
description: This table details the architecture of the video generation model, specifying the components for both the video generation backbone and the image encoders used.  It breaks down the specific parameters of each component, such as input channels, latent token channels, patch sizes, the type of positional embeddings used, and other details of the DiT blocks and different image encoders (CLIP and DINOv2).  This information is crucial for understanding the technical implementation of the model.

caption:
Table 6: Training hyperparameters. 
The right table is for stage II training.
description: This table details the hyperparameters used during the training of the Video Alchemist model. It's divided into two sections: Stage I and Stage II, representing distinct phases of the training process. For each stage, the table lists key hyperparameters, including the number of training steps, sample size, image conditioning, optimizer, learning rate, learning rate scheduler, beta, weight decay, gradient clipping, and dropout rate, along with their corresponding values.  The values for stage II often differ from those in Stage I, reflecting adjustments made to optimize the model's performance during the later phase of training.
section: B. Details of Model Architecture, Training, and Inference
